Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Independent evolution and ancestral conditions in the gnathostome axial column
Award.AbstractNarration:
The presence of a backbone, even if only made of cartilage, is the feature that distinguishes vertebrate animals from their invertebrate relatives. Despite its central position in the body plans of all jawed vertebrates, the early evolutionary history and developmental mechanisms that gave rise to the vertebral column are not well understood. Across different vertebrate groups, and among fishes in particular, the vertebrae that make up the backbone are remarkably varied in their shape, composition, and structure. Furthermore, the early fossil record of the major groups of fishes shows that many evolved fundamental components of the vertebral column quite independently of others. The goals of this project are to document vertebral development in poorly studied groups such as sharks and skates, to determine how much independent evolution actually occurred in the deep history of vertebrae, and to provide essential comparisons with the current understanding of vertebral development in bony fishes.

This project combines ancestral state reconstructions on gnathostome supertrees with computed tomography, gene expression, and fate mapping experiments to investigate the macroevolutionary patterns of vertebral evolution and development in fishes. Chondrichthyans are the main focus of the proposed research because they occupy a key phylogenetic position as the most proximate outgroup to the Osteichthyes. Chondrichthyans are often considered exemplars of ancestral vertebrate conditions in developmental and functional studies, but the primitive or derived status of much of their morphology is unclear and the subject of renewed research interest. Identifying ancestral conditions and homoplasy in the axial column complex is essential for the informed evaluation of studies and data obtained from alternative vertebrate model systems. Moreover, sharks as well as fossils are charismatic study subjects that effectively capture public interest. To help communicate the nature of this and other related projects to the public, the investigators will use computed tomographic scans (static and animated), and fossil shark specimens to educate students at local schools about the importance and relevance of evolutionary biology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The backbone is an integral part of the jawed vertebrate body plan, but gaps in our knowledge of the evolutionary history and developmental processes that form the backbone persist. This project sought to examine the evolution of the vertebral skeleton, specifically the formation of its inner-most component, the centrum. We found that centra have evolved independently up to ten times across different groups of jawed vertebrates, and that centra are constructed quite differently in these disparate groups. For example, the centra of land vertebrates (tetrapods) are somewhat homogeneous in terms of skeletal tissues and developmental origin, but the centra of many ray-finned fishes consist of multiple distinct bone layers, derived from different embryonic tissues.

This discovery prompted us to question whether the same embryonic tissues contribute to the same parts of the vertebrae in all vertebrate groups. More specifically, we set out to challenge the orthodox view that all vertebrate centra develop in much the same way. Studies on the development of the vertebrae in certain groups of jawed vertebrates have been largely absent in recent years, especially so for the cartilaginous fishes: sharks, skates, rays, and chimaeras. For this reason, we studied vertebral development in the little skate, using paraffin histology, CT scanning technology, and cellular dye-labeling. By generating thin sections as well as 3D models developed from CT scans, we identified previously undocumented features, including an unsegmented layer of tissue that extends the length of the body axis, differentiates into cartilage, and then subdivides into individual vertebral elements. We also determined that skate centra consist of three tissue layers, a characteristic that might be unique to this subgroup of cartilaginous fishes.

To establish whether all three centrum layers develop from the same embryonic source tissue, we performed experiments to track embryonic cells throughout development. We focused on two embryonic tissues, segmented cellular blocks called somites, and the rigid but flexible rod of cells that forms the notochord. We injected somites with a dye that binds to the cell membranes, allowed the embryos to develop for three months, and then identified dye-labeled cells in the developing vertebrae. We also performed complementary experiments injecting the cells that give rise to the notochord, and we discovered that the entire vertebral column in the skate, including all layers of the centrum, develops from the somite cells. When considered in conjunction with data from other jawed vertebrates, it seems likely that an exclusively somite-derived vertebral column is likely ancestral for jawed vertebrates as a whole. These results highlight the intriguing complexity of this system: very similar structures evolved many times independently, but share and repeatedly exploit common developmental components.

Throughout the course of this project we were able to interact with other biologists and non-scientists alike. By collaborating with a business start-up center at the University of Chicago, the Polsky Center, we obtained 3D printouts of four stages of embryonic skate vertebrae. We provided lab tours describing our research on cartilaginous fishes for University of Chicago alumni and members of the Marine Biological Laboratory Society. We also wrote several blog posts for the developmental biology blog, The Node, discussing this project and the process of working with skates in the lab, and used the Instagram account of the Biological Sciences Division at the University of Chicago, to share images of shark and skate research at the Marine Biological Laboratory.
